yurifromtomsk wrote:

>Hi, Colin,
>
>It's an interesting idea, that you proposed, but I would like to note 
>that there is one more way to try to tune some GA parameters (weight 
>mutation technique in this discussion). This way involves coding of 
>parameters inside the genotype, so the genome not only include 
>network information but also has a standalone gene containing weight 
>mutation type (let's say 00 -- for proportional, 01 -- for fixed 
>number and so on). During the mating, networks and these genes are 
>recombinated independently. In this case it's possible that 
>individuals that mutate defferently are present at one and the same 
>time. Thus a self-tuning is possible (with simultaneous task 
>solution!) and I think it's not so time expensive.
>
Hi Yuri,

I did consider this approach, one problem I can see is that I think lot 
more runs would be needed to seperate out genuine positive results from 
the large amount of noise. What I mean by this is that you may have a 
very poor set of mutation parameters on a gene and then it might (by 
chance) acquire a beneficial mutation, thus indicating that a poor set 
of parameters are in fact good. The reverse could also happen , where a 
good set of mutation parameters generate a good genome but then the 
params are mutated so they are not so good - the end result is we have a 
good genome that appears to have come from a poor set of parameters. We 
have to kep in mind that a genome is the result of the parameters on all 
of its ancestors, not just the parameters we end up with.

Focusing in on one set of parameters at a time keeps things simple and 
makes the results easy to interpret, there will still be a large amount 
of noise but I hope to compensate for this by performing multiple runs 
for each set of parameters and calculating an average (time to success 
or whatever). Having multiple sets of parameters in the system at a 
given time greatly increases the complexity of the system, probably 
beyond a level where we can properly comprehend everything that is going on.

Sorry to have put the dampers on your idea :)

>I think it's not so time expensive. And also if you 
>use some meta-GA, how are you going to set its' parameters?  ;) 
>  
>
You've got me there. I'm going to pick some numbers out of a hat, just 
don't tell anyone :)

Colin.
